class_notes: Course Description: This course covers the full range of Geoffrey Chaucer's poetry, including his dream visions, Troilus and Criseyde, and selected Canterbury Tales.  Chaucer creates in English the stories and forms found in classical (e.g. Ovid's Metamorphoses and Virgil¿s Aeneid), vernacular (e.g. those by Dante, Boccaccio, and Guillaume de Lorris) and biblical traditions.  Chaucer is at his best when overturning the conventions of epic, romance, fabliau, Breton lay, saint's life, and exemplum.  We shall explore at least three of the great mysteries of Chaucer¿s life and work: how such a prolific poet could also be a soldier, diplomat, and court official; how his poetic persona consistently veils and deprecates his genius; and how his relationships with people from different social classes and sexes finds poetic expression.  A class project will involve work with manuscript facsimiles in Emory's Rose Library.
course_description: Readings in The Canterbury Tales, Troilus and Criseyde, and selected other works.
schedule_location: MW 10am-11:15am in Math & Science Center - N304
